reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Court Rules Act and Small Claims Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Small Claims Rules

bcl:rule.bcl:text: If a Defendant Does Not Reply to a Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A claimant may ask for a default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a defendant does not file a reply within the time limit (see Rule 3 (4) or 1.1 (23)), the claimant may ask the registrar for a default order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge's permission needed in certain cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: No default order will be made on a counterclaim or third party notice, except under Rule 16 (6) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to ask for a default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To ask for a default order under subrule (1), a claimant must complete Form 5, following the instructions on the form, file it at the registry where the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim was filed, together with a copy of the certificate of service (Form 4) for the notice of claim or the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim, and pay the required fee.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (3), the registrar must make a default order requiring the defendant to pay immediately the amount claimed plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claim is not for a debt
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is not for a debt and the claimant completes the steps in subrule (3), the registrar must set a date for a hearing before a judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Submit documents to registry before hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least two business days before the date of a hearing set under subrule (5), a claimant must file at the registry all documents on which the claimant intends to rely at the hearing, with a supporting materials cover sheet (Form 39).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If there are other defendants
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If any other defendant has filed a reply and a date is set for a settlement conference, trial conference or trial of the claim, the hearing must be held at that time, unless a judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No notice of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant who has not filed a reply is not entitled to receive notice of a hearing under this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: A defendant loses the right to reply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After a date is set for a hearing under this rule, a defendant may not file a reply without the permission of a judge (see Rule 16 (7)).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Purpose of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The purpose of a hearing under this rule is to allow a judge to determine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount the claimant is entitled to, if the claim is for money, and
the terms of an appropriate order, in any other case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Result of hearing
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After hearing the claimant, the judge may,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the claim is for money, make a default order that requires the defendant to pay immediately the amount determined by the judge plus expenses under Rule 20 (2) and any interest the claimant is entitled to, and
in any other case, make the appropriate order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claimant does not attend at the time set for a hearing under this rule, the judge may cancel the hearing, but the claimant may ask the registrar to reschedule it.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How payment may be collected
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The creditor may collect payment under a default order by taking any of the steps listed in Rule 11 (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Before a trial date is set, a settlement conference will be held at the time and place set by the registrar.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference not required
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), a settlement conference will not be held if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 9.1 or 9.2 applies to the claim, unless an order is made under Rule 9.2 (13) (c) that the claim be set for a settlement conference under this rule,
on or before April 30, 2016, Rule 7.5 applied to the claim,
the claim relates to a motor vehicle accident and only liability for property damage is disputed, or
all of the following apply in relation to the claim:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the proceeding was started by a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim;

the civil resolution tribunal gave a final decision under section 46 (1) (a) of the Civil Resolution Tribunal Act in relation to the claim unless one of the parties did not make a response under section 7 of that Act;
a certificate referred to in Rule 1.1 (8) (b) (i) was filed with the notice of civil resolution tribunal claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some motor vehicle accident cases proceed directly to trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If subrule (2) (b) applies to the claim, the registrar must set the claim for trial and send a notice of trial to the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Some cases proceed directly to trial conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must set the claim for a trial conference if subrule (2) (c) applies to the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar must serve a notice of settlement conference (Form 6) on the parties at least 28 days before the date set for the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All parties must attend the settlement conference and have authority to settle the claim, and may be accompanied by a lawyer or articled student, except the defendant need not attend if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim results from a motor vehicle accident,
the defendant is disputing the amount of the claim but not liability, and
a person appointed by the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia attends instead of the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Relevant documents and reports
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each party to a claim must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit all relevant documents and reports to the registry at least 14 days before the date of the settlement conference, and
serve all relevant documents and reports on the other parties at least 7 days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Expenses for attending settlement conference unprepared
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a settlement conference cannot be conducted properly because a party is not prepared for it, a judge may order that party to pay the reasonable expenses of the other party or parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to change a settlement conference date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change a settlement conference date by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a consent to change the date under Rule 16 (1), or

applying for an order changing the date of the settlement conference at least 7 days before the date set for the settlement conference, unless the registrar orders otherwise, and giving whatever notice to the other party that the registrar or judge requires.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the date of the settlement conference is changed, the registrar must notify the parties of the place and time of the rescheduled conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate to be filed in personal injury cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a claim is for damages for personal injuries and the proceeding was started by a notice of claim, the claimant must file at the registry, within 6 months after serving the notice of claim and before a settlement conference is held, a certificate of readiness (Form 7) that has attached copies of all

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: medical reports, and
records of expenses or losses incurred or expected.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the claimant is not ready to file certificate
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A claimant who is not ready to file the certificate of readiness and attachments within the 6 month period may apply to the registrar (see Rule 16 (3)) to extend the time, before or after the 6 month period has expired.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Certificate must be served on other parties
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Within 14 days after filing a certificate of readiness, the claimant must serve a copy of the certificate and attachments on each of the other parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Defendant may request a medical report
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A defendant in a claim for damages for personal injuries may apply to a judge (see Rule 16 (7)) to order the claimant to attend a medical practitioner or another person who is authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession for an examination, to be paid for by the defendant.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Report to be given to claimant and provided to registry
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After receiving the medical report from the medical practitioner or other person authorized under the Health Professions Act to practise a designated health profession, the defendant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit the report to the registry at least 14 days before the date of the settlement conference, and
serve a copy of the report on the claimant at least 7 days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at a settlement conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a settlement conference, a judge may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mediate any issues being disputed;
decide on any issues that do not require evidence;
make a payment order or other appropriate order in the terms agreed to by the parties;
order that the claim be set for a trial conference under Rule 7.5;
set a trial date, if a trial is necessary;
discuss any evidence that will be required and the procedure that will be followed if a trial is necessary;
order a party to produce any information at the settlement conference or anything as evidence at trial;
order a party to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: give another party copies of documents and records by a set date, or
allow another party to inspect and copy documents and records by a set date;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if damage to property is involved in the dispute, order a party to permit a person chosen by another party to examine the property damage;
dismiss a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice if, after discussion with the parties and reviewing the filed documents, a judge determines that it

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is without reasonable grounds,
discloses no triable issue, or
is frivolous or an abuse of the court's process;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before dismissing a claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice, order a party to file an affidavit setting out further information;
order that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 148/97, s. 7 (e).]
make any other order for the just, speedy and inexpensive resolution of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If settlement conference judge orders parties to attend trial by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a judge at a settlement conference orders that a trial is to be attended by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication, the judge must also direct how, and by what date, to submit and serve any records and other things on which a party intends to rely at trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with a disclosure order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party does not comply with an order under subrule (14) (f), (g), (h) or (j), a judge may at any time do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: adjourn a settlement conference or trial and order that party to pay all the reasonable expenses incurred by any other parties as a result of the adjournment;
order a trial to proceed without permitting that party to produce as evidence any information, document or records withheld as a result of the non-compliance;
dismiss the claim, counterclaim, reply or third party notice.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a payment order is made
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a payment order is made at a settlement conference, Rule 11 (Payment of the Judgment) applies as though the payment order was made following a trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may dismiss the claim or make a payment order or other appropriate order against a party who does not attend a settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of trial date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a trial date is set at a settlement conference and a party is absent, the registrar must serve a notice of the trial date on that party unless the judge orders otherwise.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Place of the trial
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: All further steps in the claim, including the trial, will take place where the settlement conference is held except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if a judge orders otherwise, or
as provided in Rule 16 (11) and Rule 17 (8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not comply with a settlement agreement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a settlement is recorded on the court record as an agreement and not as a payment order and a party does not comply with the recorded terms of the agreement,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the agreement is cancelled, and

after filing an affidavit of non-compliance, the claimant may file a payment order in the amount that a judge directed at the settlement conference or, if no direction was made, in the amount of the claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Settlement conference — transition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of settlement conference is dated October 2, 2022 or earlier, and if the settlement conference is scheduled to take place on or after October 3, 2022, the following rules apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: despite Rule 7 (5), the parties must submit all relevant documents and reports to the registry at least two business days before the date of the settlement conference, and are not required to serve all relevant documents and reports on the other parties before the settlement conference;
despite Rule 7 (13) (a), the defendant must submit the medical report referred to in Rule 7 (13) to the registry at least two business days before the date of the settlement conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Transfer of claim to Supreme Court
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If satisfied that the monetary outcome of a claim (not including interest and expenses) may exceed $35 000, a judge must transfer the claim to the Supreme Court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on application at any time, or
on the judge's own motion at the settlement conference or trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Exception
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), a claim must not be transferred to the Supreme Court if the claimant chooses to abandon the amount over $35 000 so that the claim may be heard in the Provincial Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Personal injury claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Before transferring a claim for personal injury to the Supreme Court, a judge must consider any medical reports or records filed by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Multiple claims
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If more than one claimant has filed a notice of claim or a notice of civil resolution tribunal claim against the same defendant or defendants with respect to the same event, or if one claimant has filed notices of claim or notices of civil resolution tribunal claim against more than one defendant with respect to the same event, the judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hear at one time evidence that relates to all the claims,
apply that evidence to all the claims, and
make a decision in each of the claims,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: even though the total monetary outcome of all the claims (not including interest and expenses) is likely to exceed $35 000.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Transitional provision for Rule 7.2
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite the repeal of Rule 7.2, Rules 7.2 (27) to (29), (31) to (33) and (35) to (37) and 16 (6) (f.2) and (j), as they read on December 31, 2018, continue to apply in relation to a mediation session to which Rule 7.2 applied.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Transitional provision for Rule 7.4
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Despite the repeal of Rule 7.4, Rules 7.4 (36) to (39), (40) to (42) and (44) to (46) and 16 (6) (f.2) and (j), as they read on December 31, 2018, continue to apply in relation to a mediation session to which Rule 7.4 applied.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: insurer has the same meaning as in the Insurance Act, and includes the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia;
mediation means a collaborative process in which 2 or more parties meet and attempt, with the assistance of a mediator, to resolve issues in dispute between them;
mediation session means a meeting between 2 or more parties during which they are engaged in mediation for a period of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 2 hours,
any shorter period that the mediator may direct, or
any shorter or longer period on which the parties may agree;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mediator means a neutral and impartial facilitator with no decision making power who assists parties in negotiating a mutually acceptable settlement of issues in dispute between them;

motor vehicle action means a proceeding in which damages are claimed for injury or death, or loss of or damage to property, that arises out of the use or operation of a motor vehicle or trailer as those terms are defined in the Motor Vehicle Act;

party, in relation to a proceeding, includes an insurer of a claimant, defendant or third party if that insurer has a duty to do one or both of the following in relation to the claimant, defendant or third party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: indemnify that party for liability arising out of a claim in the proceeding;
defend any claims made against that party in the proceeding;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: roster organization means any body designated by the Attorney General to select mediators for the purposes of this rule;
third party means a person who is named as a third party under Rule 5, but does not include an insurer who has been made a third party under section 76 of the Insurance (Vehicle) Act;
third party insurer means, in relation to a designated action, an insurer that has been made a third party in an action under section 76 of the Insurance (Vehicle) Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Proceedings to which this rule applies
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (3), a party to a proceeding may initiate mediation in that proceeding under subrule (5) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the notice of claim that started the proceeding was filed after August 31, 2005, and
a claim in the proceeding amounts to more than $10 000 and not more than $35 000, without taking into account interest or claim-related expenses.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Claims to which this rule does not apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party to a proceeding may not initiate mediation in that proceeding under subrule (5) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the proceeding involves a party who has obtained one of the following against another party:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a protection order under section 183 of the Family Law Act;
a peace bond under section 810 of the Criminal Code,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 9.2 applies to a claim in the proceeding, or
the claimant, defendant and cause of action in the proceeding are the same as the plaintiff, defendant and cause of action in an action brought in the Supreme Court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When this rule ceases to apply
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule ceases to apply to a proceeding if the proceeding is transferred to the Supreme Court under Rule 7.1.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Initiating mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (7), any party to a proceeding may initiate mediation by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 (Form 29), and
delivering a copy of that filed notice to every other party named on a notice of claim, reply or third party notice that has been filed in the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 must be delivered
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 must not be filed and delivered under subrule (5) until a reply has been filed in the proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Not more than one mediation under this rule in any proceeding
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, not more than one mediation may be initiated under this rule in relation to any proceeding.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rule does not apply unless mediation is initiated under subrules (5) and (6)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrules (9) to (53) do not apply to a proceeding unless mediation is initiated in that proceeding under subrule (5).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Appointment of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The parties must jointly appoint a mutually acceptable mediator within 14 days after the Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 has been delivered to all parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to roster organization
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties do not jointly appoint a mutually acceptable mediator within the time required by subrule (9), any party may apply to a roster organization for an appointment of a mediator.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Roster organization's appointment procedure
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application to a roster organization is made under subrule (10), the roster organization must select a mediator after taking into account

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the need for the mediator to be neutral and independent,
the qualifications of the mediator,
the mediator's fees,
the mediator's availability,
the nature of the dispute, and
any other consideration likely to result in the selection of an impartial, competent and effective mediator.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notification of selection of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Promptly after selecting a mediator under subrule (11), the roster organization must notify the parties in writing of that selection.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Deemed date of appointment of mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The mediator selected under subrule (11) is deemed to be appointed by the parties on the date that notice of that selection is sent under subrule (12).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Replacement of appointed mediator
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the mediator selected by the roster organization under subrule (11) is unable or unwilling to act as mediator,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the selected mediator or any party may notify the roster organization of that inability or unwillingness, and
the roster organization must, within 7 days after receiving that notice, select a new mediator in accordance with subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Mediator's role
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The mediator may conduct the mediation session at the location and in any manner the mediator considers appropriate to assist the parties to reach a resolution that is fair, timely and cost-effective.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Scheduling of mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A mediation session must occur within 60 days after the appointment of the mediator, and at least 7 days before the date set under Rule 7 for the settlement conference unless a later specified date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is agreed on by all parties and that agreement is confirmed by the mediator in writing, or
is ordered by the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending the mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In the case of a claim that is not a motor vehicle action,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who delivers a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 under subrule (5) and each of the following parties must attend the mediation session unless exempted from attending under subrule (29):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claimant;
the defendant;
the third party, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each insurer of a claimant, defendant or third party may attend the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending the mediation session in a motor vehicle action
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In the case of a motor vehicle action, the party who delivers a Notice to Mediate for Claims Between $10 000 and $35 000 under subrule (5) and each of the following parties must attend the mediation session unless exempted from attending under subrule (29):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claimant;
the insurer of the defendant or, if the defendant is not insured, the defendant;
the insurer of the third party or, if the third party is not insured, the third party;
each third party insurer to the action.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Requirements on parties who attend mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each person who attends a mediation session must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have authority to settle, and
before the mediation session, provide to the mediator and serve on the other parties all documents and reports that are relevant to the dispute.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Representative may attend for any party who is not an individual
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may attend a mediation session by representative if the party is not an individual.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Authority of representative
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A representative who attends a mediation session under subrule (20) in the place of a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be familiar with all facts relevant to the dispute, and

have full authority to settle, or have access at the earliest practicable opportunity to a person who has, or to a group of persons who collectively have, full authority to settle, on behalf of the party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Party or representative may be accompanied by a lawyer
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person or representative who attends a mediation session may be accompanied by a lawyer or articled student.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other persons may attend with consent
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any other person may attend a mediation session if that attendance is permitted by the mediator and consented to by the parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Attending a mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: One or more of the persons who are required or permitted to attend a mediation session under subrule (17), (18) or (23) may attend the mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all of the other persons attending the mediation session consent, or
subject to subrule (26), the registrar authorizes that attendance under subrule (25).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application to attend mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may authorize one or more persons who are required or permitted to attend a mediation session under subrule (17), (18) or (23) to attend the mediation session by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication if an application for that authorization is made to the registrar under Rule 16 (3) at least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Late application to attend mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application for an authorization under subrule (25) is made to the registrar under Rule 16 (3) within 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, the registrar may make that authorization if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it was not reasonably practicable for that person to bring an application under subrule (25) at least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, or
exceptional circumstances exist.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If application is granted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an application under subrule (25) or (26) is granted, the registrar may order the person requesting to attend the mediation by telephone, video conference or other means of electronic communication to pay for the telephone call, video conference or other cost of that person's attendance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for exemption
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 14 days before the date set for the mediation session, a party may apply to a judge under Rule 16 (7) to exempt a claim from the application of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When a judge may grant an exemption
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On an application under subrule (28), a judge may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt a claim from the application of this rule if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: all of the parties have previously engaged in a mediation of the matters in issue, or
it is unfair or impractical to require mediation, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempt one or more of the parties from attending the mediation session if, in the judge's opinion, it is unfair or impractical to require the party to attend.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Adjourning a mediation session
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for the mediation session, a party may apply to the registrar to adjourn the mediation session and that party must give to the other parties whatever notice of the application the registrar may order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Date may be changed to avoid hardship
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The registrar may adjourn a mediation session under subrule (30) if the party applying for that adjournment satisfies the registrar that the original date is unreasonably inconvenient to the party, and, without limiting this, the registrar may determine that a date is unreasonably inconvenient to a party if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a family emergency renders the party unable to attend on the day set for the mediation session, or
the party is required to attend court on the day set for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of change of date
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the registrar adjourns a mediation session under subrule (31),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who applied for the adjournment must give to the other parties whatever notice of the adjournment the registrar may order, and
the parties must jointly set a new date, satisfactory to the mediator, for the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Fee declaration
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The parties who attend the mediation session must complete and sign a fee declaration (Form 30) before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Corporation may sign by representative
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: For the purposes of subrule (33), a party that is a corporation may sign the fee declaration by its representative.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Form of fee declaration
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A fee declaration under subrule (33) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disclose the cost of the mediation services, and
contain a declaration by the parties signing the fee declaration that the costs of the mediation will be paid

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: equally by all of the following who attend the mediation session or their insurers:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: each claimant;
each defendant;
each third party, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on any other basis that has been agreed to by those parties and is specified in the fee declaration.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Costs may be paid on a different basis
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The cost of the mediation must be paid on the basis set out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the fee declaration, or

if the parties who signed the fee declaration agree to a different basis for sharing that cost and that basis is included in the mediation agreement referred to in subrule (48) (b), on the basis included in the mediation agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a party does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who is required to attend a mediation session does not attend the mediation session or does not sign a fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: complete a verification of default (Form 31) in accordance with the instructions on the form, and
give the completed form to the parties attending, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any one of the parties attending the mediation session may file the completed verification of default at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What the registrar will do if a claimant does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a verification of default is filed in relation to a claimant in a proceeding,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the defendant in the proceeding may, by filing a request for judgment or for dismissal (Form 23) and paying the required fee, ask the registrar to make an order dismissing the claimant's claim, and
the registrar may make an order dismissing the claimant's claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a defendant or insurer does not attend
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A verification of default may be filed in relation to a defendant, including, without limitation, a defendant to a counterclaim and a defendant to a third party notice, in the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which the defendant is insured, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the insurer of the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which the defendant is not insured, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a motor vehicle action in relation to which there is a third party insurer, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the third party insurer did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in any other case, a verification of default may be filed in relation to the defendant if the defendant did not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attend the mediation session, or
sign the fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The following apply if a verification of default is filed under subrule (39):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the verification of default is filed in relation to a defendant who is named as a defendant on the notice of claim,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the claimant may, by filing a request for judgment or for dismissal and paying the required fee, ask the registrar to proceed under these rules as if the defendant had not filed a reply and the claimant had completed the steps in Rule 6 (3), and
the registrar must either make a default order under Rule 6 (4) or set a date under Rule 6 (5) for a hearing before a judge;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the verification of default is filed in relation to a defendant to a counterclaim or a defendant to a third party notice, the party bringing the counterclaim or third party notice may apply under Rule 16 (7) for a default order under Rule 16 (6) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no party attends
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If no party attends a mediation session,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a verification of default in accordance with the instructions on the form, and file the completed form at the registry, and
the registrar must make an order dismissing each disputed claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of a dismissal or default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party against whom an order is made under subrule (38) (b), (39) (b) or (41) (b) for not attending a mediation session or for not signing a fee declaration before, or at the beginning of, the mediation session may apply under Rule 16 (7) to a judge to cancel the order, and the judge may cancel the order under Rule 16 (6) (j).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What application must contain
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party seeking an order under subrule (42) must attach to the application an affidavit containing the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the reason for not attending the mediation session or for failing to sign the fee declaration;
the reason for any delay, if there has been delay in filing the application;
the facts that support the claim or defence.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a judge cancels a dismissal or default order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge who cancels a dismissal order or default order made under this rule may also do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the disputed claims proceed to mediation on any terms the judge considers appropriate;
order the payment of any expenses incurred by the party or parties who did attend;
order that a settlement conference or trial be held;
make any other order that the judge considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Disclosure and compellability
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (46) and (47), a person must not disclose, or be compelled to disclose, in any proceeding oral or written information acquired in or in connection with a mediation session.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Exceptions
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subrule (45) does not apply

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of any information, opinion, document, offer or admission that all of the parties agree in writing may be disclosed,
to any mediation agreement or fee declaration made during or in connection with a mediation session,
to any threats of bodily harm made during or in connection with a mediation session, or
to any information that does not identify the parties and that is disclosed for research or statistical purposes only.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No restriction on otherwise producible information
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Nothing in this rule precludes a party from introducing into evidence in any proceeding any information or records produced in the course of the mediation that are otherwise producible or compellable in those proceedings.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If the parties reach agreement on all or some issues
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties reach an agreement at mediation on all or some issues,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a result of mediation form (Form 24) and file the completed form at the registry, and
the parties must complete and sign a mediation agreement (Form 25) and any one of those parties may file the agreement at the registry.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If payment terms are not complied with
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party fails to comply with a provision of a filed mediation agreement, the party not in default may, if that provision required a payment of money,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file an affidavit of non-compliance at the registry, and
after that, file a payment order at the registry for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the amount specified in the mediation agreement less any amount already paid in compliance with the mediation agreement, or
if no amount was specified in the mediation agreement, for the amount of the claim less any amount already paid in compliance with the mediation agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If other terms are not complied with
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party fails to comply with a provision of a filed mediation agreement and that provision was not one requiring a payment of money, the party not in default may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the mediation agreement establishes an amount of liquidated damages that is to be payable in the event of such a default, file at the registry an affidavit of non-compliance and a payment order for that amount, or
if the mediation agreement does not establish a liquidated damages amount in relation to the breached provision, seek a mediation compensation order (Form 26) under Rule 16 (6) (f.2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Mediation compensation order
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge may make a mediation compensation order under subrule (50) (b) if a party applies for that order (see Rule 16 (7)) and attaches to the application an affidavit of non-compliance.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If a dispute is not resolved
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the parties do not reach agreement at mediation on all the issues,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the mediator must complete a result of mediation form and file the completed form at the registry, and
after that, the registrar must set one of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: subject to subparagraph (iii), a settlement conference, if a settlement conference has not been completed;
a trial, if a settlement conference has been completed;
a trial conference, if the completed result of mediation form is filed at the Robson Square Small Claims Registry after November 25, 2007.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Concluding a mediation
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A mediation is concluded when

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all issues are resolved, or
the mediator terminates the mediation.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 244/2015, Sch. 3, s. 3.]
